title: Can we zoom out a bit more?
body: Seeing more on one screen would be nice.

replies.body: The FoV that you have is actually an integral part of the game design and balance. If they nudge it out slightly, it would have much larger implications that you might think. And after they adjust balance and design to account for that FoV, you're likely going to be left wishing the FoV were slightly wider yet. If they change it, it'll just start a cycle of wanting to zoom out even more and more.

First of all, slippery slope fallacy. People would stop wanting a bigger screen when their screen exceeds a champion's vision range.

Second of all, all it would do is put more power in the hands of newer players who aren't comfortable or proficient at unlocking the camera and using freecam. It wouldn't break the game, it would be a crutch for players who don't have the camera control that higher skilled ones do.

This is a benefit to it, yes. But I disagree that it doesn't break the game (or at least require major changes if they do it). The FoV used is as integral to the balance of the game as Flash's existence is. On top of that, we already see how awkwardly slow everything looks when Riot zooms out in the LCS broadcasts. Work would definitely need to be done.

And I acknowledge making a statement that pushes a slippery slope. But I do still believe that, within reason, players are always going to want more information available to them than what they have. Information is incredibly valuable in a game like this. And I also believe that, when making the game originally, had Riot set the max FoV to something wider than we have now, this conversation would still be happening due to the value of information.

And thank you for actually contributing to the discussion rather than dismissing arguments entirely due to a single statement.

Information is important, yes, but I'd argue that actual vision (revealing the fog of war) is the more important factor, not how much of the map you can see on your screen, especially when you consider that you can already see the whole map on your screen at once via the minimap; having the ability to zoom out further just increases the amount of that information you have rendered on your screen in graphic detail, and how much of it you can click on.

If you interpret the minimap as having the entire map in your view, the only adverse benefit that would affect a champion's power/behavior to having the game's FoV increased by enlarged camera zoom would be a larger area where you can precisely point and click. The only champions that would have their power shifted by this benefit are ones with long-ranged skill shots that don't already have special FoV alterations built in (e.g. Xerath and Jhin ultimates). Draven and Jinx ultimates might become easier to use, and long range snipes with Jhin's W that would otherwise be just off screen would be more reliable, but that's all I can think of.

Champions are designed to operate within the given FoV window that you see in-game, and letting players see just beyond that window wouldn't be game breaking. It would just put more information at the forefront of a player's mind if they aren't in the habit of keeping the minimap in mind and using freecam regularly.

Keep in mind that when I hear "let us zoom out more" what I have in my mind is something to the effect of seeing a half-inch (or centimeter) in any direction beyond the FoV of current default zoom at the very most, just because I feel like on-screen visuals feel a little cramped with the area where I'm interacting with the playing field. I don't want an expansive cinematic bird's-eye overhead of my lane, just a little more distance between where UI elements are and where I'm pointing and clicking the most. I doubt I'd notice any awkward slowness from being zoomed out just a little further. I don't know for sure, but I'd like to give it a try.

Relative to your FoV, models all shrink. Particles shrink. Hitboxes shrink. It would vary by ability, but some things may become easier to land, other more difficult.

Regarding vision, the minimap doesn't show you nearly as much as what's on the screen itself. But I do think there's a lot of value when you start showing a lot more than the normal fog of war radius on the screen. Yes, normally this will be hidden, but it's not uncommon to have wards in the nearby areas of the FoW that are important (especially during laning). So you would certainly be able to see more than you can now, despite FoW.

Also, there are other factors, too. With a larger area in view at all times, it may be the difference between noticing that Ashe ult on the way and sidestepping just in time, or getting hit.

I'm not really trying to say these things are inherently bad or inherently good. They're just points you'd have to think about when you go to address the balance of the game after making such a change. This is where I question whether the work required from such a change is justified by what's gained.

So we've boiled it down to a conundrum that can never be really solved. I say increasing the zoom wouldn't require many changes, you say it would, and neither stance can be proven or disproven without actually implementing the change and testing the waters for how much would need to be adjusted.

Personally, I physically don't have the mechanical ability to use the unlocked camera, my crappy laptop can't handle it. I've been using the locked camera for 8 years or so, and after 7 years I finally got into ranked. (Too many trolls in the early years of bronze) But using just the locked camera I went from bronze 5 to gold 5 in 3 months. 
From personal experience, I believe it takes more skill to be good at league with a locked camera because you have to adapt your positioning for the lack of expanded vision. I will be the first to admit that I've died from a gank I didn't see coming but could have, had I had,{{item:3348}}  a better camera angle.
slippery slope argument.

Of course there's a point where it becomes unreasonable. But you can't just ignore that FoV is an integral part of the game design, either. If the game were designed to have a larger FoV, there would likely still be people asking for a wider FoV. 

Why make a change that requires a complete overhaul on the game when the benefits are minimal, and you'll never please everybody?

> Of course there's a point where it becomes unreasonable.

So zooming out slightly wouldn't in fact lead to that unreasonable state. Ok then, we can better optimize the FOV. 

> Why make a change that requires a complete overhaul on the game when the benefits are minimal, 

Overhaul? Really? Watch some LCS games and watch how they zoom the camera out. You get information about the entire fight and that could hardly be considered a minimal change ... it actually amazes me that having knowledge of a fight happening around you is marginalized by you and others here. 

> and you'll never please everybody?

Don't let the perfect be the enemy of the good. You don't have to have 100% approval over a change to make things better than they are. This is a suggestion for improvement, not meant to make the game perfect for everyone, and the hypothetical people you cite who would not be pleased still would be happy over increasing the FOV, they just want it to be farther out still so they would get an improvement. The change would make some people happier, while having no effect on others. Where is the downside then?

>So zooming out slightly wouldn't in fact lead to that unreasonable state. Ok then, we can better optimize the FOV.

Nice try. You know that's not what I was talking about. Obviously, there's a point where you've zoomed out too much for the game to be playable (see sarcastic comments about just making the minimap full-screen and playing on that). 

But zooming out a little bit *would* require big changes to the game in terms of balance, models, animations, etc. 

> Watch some LCS games and watch how they zoom the camera out. 

I have, and it looks awful when they do that. Animations looks clunky, the whole game appears to be moving in slow motion. It highlights exactly why major changes *would* be needed. 

>You get information about the entire fight and that could hardly be considered a minimal change ... it actually >amazes me that having knowledge of a fight happening around you is marginalized by you and others here.

How is "this would require major balance changes" minimizing how that extra knowledge changes the game? Of course it's a huge deal. 

The question is really...why? Sure, people have more info visible on the screen. But there will always be more information you could have that's just off the screen. Why make an arbitrary change to something that's so central to the game design? The benefits to the gameplay experience overall would have to be massive in order to justify the work required.

> But zooming out a little bit would require big changes to the game in terms of balance, models, animations, etc. 

Balance changes? Please explain. 

Models? Animations? We already see how the game looks zoomed out more, in LCS replays and when using Jhin or Xerath ults and it looks fine. 

> I have, and it looks awful when they do that. Animations looks clunky, the whole game appears to be moving in slow motion. It highlights exactly why major changes would be needed.

A jungler sneaking up in your corner spot, only for you to see them miles away due to a further FOW, fucks over people. Artillery mages now get easy aiming as opposed to before, as they need to either scroll the screen further away, or predict.
